description: Explore atomic structure, chemical bonding, states of matter, and reaction kinetics that govern chemical behavior

slides.title: Welcome to Physical Chemistry
slides.content:
# Introduction to Physical Chemistry

Welcome to **Physical Chemistry** - the branch that applies physics principles to understand chemical systems!

## What You Will Learn:
- **Atomic Structure** - How atoms are built
- **Electron Configuration** - Where electrons reside
- **Chemical Bonding** - How atoms connect
- **States of Matter** - Solid, liquid, gas behavior
- **Reaction Kinetics** - How fast reactions occur
- **Chemical Equilibrium** - Balance in reactions

> **Fun Fact:** Physical chemistry bridges physics and chemistry, using math to predict chemical behavior!

## Why Physical Chemistry Matters:
- Explains WHY reactions happen
- Predicts reaction rates and outcomes
- Essential for drug development
- Critical for materials science
- Foundation for understanding energy changes

## The Big Questions:

| Question | Physical Chemistry Answers |
|----------|---------------------------|
| Why do atoms bond? | Energy minimization |
| Why are some reactions fast? | Activation energy |
| Why do gases expand? | Kinetic theory |
| Why do reactions stop? | Equilibrium |

Let's explore the physics behind chemistry!

slides.title: Atomic Structure
slides.content:
# Atomic Structure

Atoms are the fundamental building blocks of matter.

## Subatomic Particles:

| Particle | Charge | Mass (amu) | Location |
|----------|--------|------------|----------|
| Proton | +1 | 1.007 | Nucleus |
| Neutron | 0 | 1.009 | Nucleus |
| Electron | -1 | 0.00055 | Orbitals |

## Atomic Numbers:

### Atomic Number (Z):
- Number of protons
- Defines the element
- Equal to electrons in neutral atom

### Mass Number (A):
- Protons + Neutrons
- Written as superscript

### Notation:
```
A
 Z X

Example: Carbon-12 = 12/6 C (6 protons, 6 neutrons)
```

## Isotopes:

- Same element (same Z)
- Different number of neutrons
- Different mass numbers

### Examples:
| Isotope | Protons | Neutrons | Stable? |
|---------|---------|----------|--------|
| C-12 | 6 | 6 | Yes |
| C-13 | 6 | 7 | Yes |
| C-14 | 6 | 8 | No (radioactive) |

## Atomic Mass:

- Weighted average of all isotopes
- Based on natural abundance
- Why atomic masses aren't whole numbers

> **Scale:** If the nucleus were a marble, the atom would be the size of a football stadium!

slides.title: Electron Configuration
slides.content:
# Electron Configuration

Electrons occupy specific **energy levels** and **orbitals** around the nucleus.

## Energy Levels (Shells):

| Level (n) | Max Electrons | Subshells |
|-----------|---------------|----------|
| 1 | 2 | 1s |
| 2 | 8 | 2s, 2p |
| 3 | 18 | 3s, 3p, 3d |
| 4 | 32 | 4s, 4p, 4d, 4f |

## Subshells and Orbitals:

| Subshell | Shape | Orbitals | Max e- |
|----------|-------|----------|--------|
| s | Sphere | 1 | 2 |
| p | Dumbbell | 3 | 6 |
| d | Cloverleaf | 5 | 10 |
| f | Complex | 7 | 14 |

## Filling Rules:

### 1. Aufbau Principle:
Electrons fill lowest energy orbitals first.

**Filling order:** 1s, 2s, 2p, 3s, 3p, 4s, 3d, 4p, 5s, 4d...

### 2. Pauli Exclusion Principle:
No two electrons can have same four quantum numbers.
(Max 2 electrons per orbital, with opposite spins)

### 3. Hund's Rule:
Electrons fill orbitals singly before pairing.

## Writing Configurations:

| Element | Atomic # | Configuration |
|---------|----------|---------------|
| H | 1 | 1s1 |
| C | 6 | 1s2 2s2 2p2 |
| Na | 11 | 1s2 2s2 2p6 3s1 |
| Fe | 26 | [Ar] 3d6 4s2 |

> **Noble Gas Shorthand:** Use [He], [Ne], [Ar], etc. to abbreviate inner electrons.

slides.title: Atomic Structure Quiz
slides.content: Test your understanding of electron configuration!
slides.quizQuestion: What is the electron configuration of oxygen (atomic number 8)?

slides.title: Ionic Bonding
slides.content:
# Ionic Bonding

**Ionic bonds** form when electrons transfer from one atom to another.

## How Ionic Bonds Form:

1. Metal atom loses electron(s) -> becomes positive ion (cation)
2. Non-metal atom gains electron(s) -> becomes negative ion (anion)
3. Opposite charges attract -> ionic bond

## Example: Sodium Chloride (NaCl)

```
Na (2,8,1) -> Na+ (2,8) + e-
Cl (2,8,7) + e- -> Cl- (2,8,8)
Na+ + Cl- -> NaCl
```

## Characteristics of Ionic Compounds:

| Property | Description |
|----------|-------------|
| Crystal structure | Regular 3D lattice |
| Melting point | High (strong bonds) |
| Conductivity (solid) | Poor (ions fixed) |
| Conductivity (molten/dissolved) | Good (ions mobile) |
| Solubility | Often soluble in water |
| Brittleness | Brittle (layers shift) |

## Lattice Energy:

**Lattice energy** is energy released when ionic crystal forms.

### Factors affecting lattice energy:
- Higher charges = stronger attraction
- Smaller ions = stronger attraction

| Compound | Lattice Energy (kJ/mol) |
|----------|------------------------|
| NaCl | 787 |
| MgO | 3850 |
| NaF | 923 |

## Formula Writing:

- Charges must balance to zero
- NaCl: Na+ and Cl- (1:1)
- MgCl2: Mg2+ and Cl- (1:2)
- Al2O3: Al3+ and O2- (2:3)

> **Why salt dissolves:** Water molecules surround and separate ions, breaking the lattice.

slides.title: Covalent Bonding
slides.content:
# Covalent Bonding

**Covalent bonds** form when atoms share electrons.

## How Covalent Bonds Form:

- Usually between non-metals
- Shared electrons attracted by both nuclei
- Each atom achieves stable electron configuration

## Types of Covalent Bonds:

### By Number of Shared Pairs:

| Bond Type | Shared Pairs | Example |
|-----------|--------------|--------|
| Single | 1 pair (2 e-) | H-H |
| Double | 2 pairs (4 e-) | O=O |
| Triple | 3 pairs (6 e-) | N:::N |

### By Electron Distribution:

**Nonpolar Covalent:**
- Equal sharing
- Same or similar electronegativity
- Example: H2, O2, Cl2

**Polar Covalent:**
- Unequal sharing
- Different electronegativity
- Example: H2O, HCl

## Electronegativity:

**Electronegativity** = ability to attract shared electrons

| Element | Electronegativity |
|---------|------------------|
| F | 4.0 (highest) |
| O | 3.5 |
| N | 3.0 |
| C | 2.5 |
| H | 2.1 |
| Na | 0.9 |

### Bond Type by Electronegativity Difference:

| Difference | Bond Type |
|------------|----------|
| 0 - 0.4 | Nonpolar covalent |
| 0.5 - 1.7 | Polar covalent |
| > 1.7 | Ionic |

## Properties of Covalent Compounds:

- Lower melting/boiling points than ionic
- Often gases or liquids at room temperature
- Poor electrical conductivity
- May be soluble in organic solvents

> **The Octet Rule:** Atoms tend to gain, lose, or share electrons to have 8 valence electrons (like noble gases).

slides.title: Metallic Bonding
slides.content:
# Metallic Bonding

**Metallic bonds** form from a "sea" of delocalized electrons shared among metal atoms.

## The Electron Sea Model:

- Metal atoms release valence electrons
- Electrons move freely throughout metal
- Positive metal ions in a sea of electrons
- Electrostatic attraction holds metal together

## Characteristics:

| Property | Explanation |
|----------|-------------|
| Electrical conductivity | Free electrons carry current |
| Thermal conductivity | Free electrons transfer heat |
| Malleability | Layers can slide (no directional bonds) |
| Ductility | Can be drawn into wires |
| Luster | Free electrons reflect light |
| High melting points | Strong metallic attraction |

## Metallic Bond Strength:

Affected by:
- Number of valence electrons (more = stronger)
- Atomic radius (smaller = stronger)
- Packing efficiency

| Metal | Melting Point (C) | Valence e- |
|-------|-------------------|------------|
| Na | 98 | 1 |
| Mg | 650 | 2 |
| Al | 660 | 3 |
| Fe | 1538 | 2-3 |
| W | 3422 | 6 |

## Alloys:

**Alloys** are mixtures of metals (sometimes with non-metals).

| Alloy | Components | Properties |
|-------|------------|------------|
| Steel | Fe + C | Stronger than pure Fe |
| Bronze | Cu + Sn | Harder than Cu |
| Brass | Cu + Zn | Corrosion resistant |
| Stainless steel | Fe + Cr + Ni | Rust resistant |

> **Why metals conduct:** Unlike ionic compounds, metals conduct as solids because electrons are always free to move!

slides.title: States of Matter
slides.content:
# States of Matter

Matter exists in three common states: **solid**, **liquid**, and **gas**.

## Particle Theory:

### Solid:
- Particles closely packed in fixed positions
- Strong forces between particles
- Particles vibrate but don't move
- Fixed shape and volume

### Liquid:
- Particles close but can move past each other
- Moderate forces between particles
- Fixed volume but takes container shape

### Gas:
- Particles far apart and moving rapidly
- Weak/no forces between particles
- No fixed shape or volume
- Fills entire container

## Comparison:

| Property | Solid | Liquid | Gas |
|----------|-------|--------|-----|
| Shape | Fixed | Container | Container |
| Volume | Fixed | Fixed | Container |
| Compressibility | Very low | Very low | High |
| Density | High | Medium | Low |
| Particle motion | Vibration | Sliding | Random rapid |

## Phase Transitions:

| Transition | Name | Energy |
|------------|------|--------|
| Solid -> Liquid | Melting | Absorbed |
| Liquid -> Solid | Freezing | Released |
| Liquid -> Gas | Evaporation/Boiling | Absorbed |
| Gas -> Liquid | Condensation | Released |
| Solid -> Gas | Sublimation | Absorbed |
| Gas -> Solid | Deposition | Released |

## Plasma:

**Fourth state of matter:**
- Ionized gas
- Contains free electrons and ions
- Found in stars, lightning, neon signs
- Most common state in universe

> **Temperature is key:** Adding heat increases particle motion, eventually causing phase changes.

slides.title: Bonding Quiz
slides.content: Test your knowledge of chemical bonding!
slides.quizQuestion: Which property is characteristic of metallic bonding?

slides.title: Gas Laws
slides.content:
# Gas Laws

Gases follow predictable relationships between pressure, volume, and temperature.

## Key Variables:
- **P** = Pressure (atm, Pa, kPa)
- **V** = Volume (L, m^3)
- **T** = Temperature (Kelvin)
- **n** = Amount (moles)

## Individual Gas Laws:

### Boyle's Law (T constant):
```
P1 x V1 = P2 x V2
```
Pressure and volume are inversely proportional.

### Charles's Law (P constant):
```
V1 / T1 = V2 / T2
```
Volume and temperature are directly proportional.

### Gay-Lussac's Law (V constant):
```
P1 / T1 = P2 / T2
```
Pressure and temperature are directly proportional.

### Avogadro's Law (P, T constant):
```
V1 / n1 = V2 / n2
```
Volume and amount are directly proportional.

## Combined Gas Law:
```
(P1 x V1) / T1 = (P2 x V2) / T2
```

## Ideal Gas Law:
```
PV = nRT
```

Where R = 8.314 J/(mol K) = 0.0821 L atm/(mol K)

## Standard Conditions:
- **STP:** 0 C (273 K), 1 atm
- At STP, 1 mol of ideal gas = 22.4 L

## Example:
5 L of gas at 300 K is heated to 450 K at constant pressure. New volume?
```
V2 = V1 x (T2/T1) = 5 x (450/300) = 7.5 L
```

> **Kinetic Theory:** Gas laws come from molecular motion - higher T means faster molecules!

slides.title: Reaction Rates
slides.content:
# Reaction Rates

**Reaction rate** measures how fast reactants convert to products.

## Measuring Reaction Rate:

```
Rate = Change in concentration / Time
Rate = -d[Reactant]/dt = +d[Product]/dt
```

## Factors Affecting Rate:

### 1. Concentration:
- Higher concentration = faster reaction
- More particles = more collisions

### 2. Temperature:
- Higher temperature = faster reaction
- Particles have more energy
- Rule of thumb: 10 C increase doubles rate

### 3. Surface Area:
- Greater surface area = faster reaction
- More exposure for collisions
- Powder reacts faster than chunks

### 4. Catalysts:
- Increase rate without being consumed
- Lower activation energy
- Provide alternative pathway

### 5. Nature of Reactants:
- Ionic reactions often fast
- Reactions breaking strong bonds are slower

## Collision Theory:

For reaction to occur:
1. Particles must **collide**
2. With sufficient **energy** (>= activation energy)
3. In correct **orientation**

## Rate Laws:

```
Rate = k[A]^m[B]^n
```

Where:
- **k** = rate constant
- **m, n** = reaction orders (from experiment)
- **[A], [B]** = concentrations

## Example Orders:

| Order | Rate doubles when... |
|-------|----------------------|
| Zero (0) | Concentration doesn't affect rate |
| First (1) | Concentration doubles |
| Second (2) | Concentration doubles |

> **Catalytic converters:** They speed up reactions that convert toxic exhaust gases to less harmful products.

slides.title: Activation Energy
slides.content:
# Activation Energy

**Activation energy (Ea)** is the minimum energy required for a reaction to occur.

## Energy Diagrams:

### Exothermic Reaction:
```
Reactants     
    \        <- Activation Energy
     \      
      \_____/
           \
            \Products (lower energy)
```
- Products lower than reactants
- Energy released to surroundings
- Delta H is negative

### Endothermic Reaction:
```
              Products (higher energy)
             /
      ______/
     /      <- Activation Energy
    /
Reactants
```
- Products higher than reactants
- Energy absorbed from surroundings
- Delta H is positive

## Arrhenius Equation:

```
k = A x e^(-Ea/RT)
```

Where:
- **k** = rate constant
- **A** = frequency factor
- **Ea** = activation energy
- **R** = gas constant (8.314 J/mol K)
- **T** = temperature (K)

## Effect of Temperature:

| Temperature | Effect on Rate |
|-------------|---------------|
| Increase | Rate increases exponentially |
| Decrease | Rate decreases exponentially |

## Catalysts and Activation Energy:

- Catalysts **lower** activation energy
- Provide alternative reaction pathway
- More molecules have sufficient energy
- Rate increases

### Types of Catalysts:

| Type | Description | Example |
|------|-------------|--------|
| Homogeneous | Same phase as reactants | Acid catalysis |
| Heterogeneous | Different phase | Metal surface |
| Enzyme | Biological catalyst | Amylase |

> **Why refrigeration works:** Lower temperature means fewer molecules have enough energy to react, slowing food spoilage.

slides.title: Chemical Equilibrium
slides.content:
# Chemical Equilibrium

**Equilibrium** is reached when forward and reverse reaction rates are equal.

## Dynamic Equilibrium:

- Reactions continue in both directions
- No NET change in concentrations
- System appears static but is dynamic

## Equilibrium Expression:

For reaction: aA + bB <-> cC + dD

```
K = [C]^c x [D]^d / ([A]^a x [B]^b)
```

Where K = equilibrium constant

## Meaning of K:

| K Value | Equilibrium Position |
|---------|---------------------|
| K >> 1 | Favors products |
| K << 1 | Favors reactants |
| K approx 1 | Significant amounts of both |

## Le Chatelier's Principle:

> **When a system at equilibrium is disturbed, it shifts to counteract the change.**

### Stress and Response:

| Stress | System Response |
|--------|----------------|
| Add reactant | Shifts toward products |
| Remove product | Shifts toward products |
| Add product | Shifts toward reactants |
| Increase pressure | Shifts to side with fewer gas moles |
| Increase temperature | Shifts in endothermic direction |
| Add catalyst | NO shift (reaches equilibrium faster) |

## Example:
```
N2(g) + 3H2(g) <-> 2NH3(g) + heat
```

- Adding N2: Shifts right (more NH3)
- Removing NH3: Shifts right
- Increasing pressure: Shifts right (4 moles -> 2 moles)
- Increasing temperature: Shifts left (exothermic)

> **Industrial application:** The Haber process uses Le Chatelier's principle to maximize ammonia production.

slides.title: Equilibrium Quiz
slides.content: Test your understanding of equilibrium!
slides.quizQuestion: For an exothermic reaction at equilibrium, increasing temperature will:

slides.title: Enthalpy and Energy Changes
slides.content:
# Enthalpy and Energy Changes

**Enthalpy (H)** is the heat content of a system at constant pressure.

## Enthalpy Change (Delta H):

```
Delta H = H_products - H_reactants
```

### Exothermic Reactions:
- Delta H < 0 (negative)
- Heat released to surroundings
- Products have less energy
- Examples: Combustion, neutralization

### Endothermic Reactions:
- Delta H > 0 (positive)
- Heat absorbed from surroundings
- Products have more energy
- Examples: Photosynthesis, melting ice

## Types of Enthalpy:

| Type | Symbol | Definition |
|------|--------|------------|
| Formation | Delta H_f | Form compound from elements |
| Combustion | Delta H_c | Complete burning in O2 |
| Neutralization | Delta H_n | Acid + base reaction |
| Atomization | Delta H_at | Form gaseous atoms |

## Hess's Law:

> **The enthalpy change for a reaction is the same regardless of the route taken.**

This allows calculation of unknown enthalpy changes.

## Bond Enthalpies:

```
Delta H = Bonds broken - Bonds formed
```

| Bond | Energy (kJ/mol) |
|------|----------------|
| C-H | 413 |
| C-C | 347 |
| C=C | 614 |
| O-H | 463 |
| O=O | 498 |

## Calorimetry:

Measuring heat changes:
```
q = m x c x Delta T
```

Where:
- q = heat (J)
- m = mass (g)
- c = specific heat capacity (J/g K)
- Delta T = temperature change (K)

> **Energy conservation:** Total energy before reaction = Total energy after reaction (just in different forms).

slides.title: Intermolecular Forces
slides.content:
# Intermolecular Forces

**Intermolecular forces** are attractions between molecules (not within molecules).

## Types of Intermolecular Forces:

### 1. London Dispersion Forces (Weakest):
- Present in ALL molecules
- Caused by temporary dipoles
- Stronger with more electrons
- Only force in nonpolar molecules

### 2. Dipole-Dipole Forces:
- Between polar molecules
- Positive end attracts negative end
- Stronger than London forces

### 3. Hydrogen Bonding (Strongest):
- Special dipole-dipole interaction
- H bonded to F, O, or N
- H attracted to lone pair on F, O, or N
- Responsible for water's unique properties

## Comparison:

| Force | Strength | Example |
|-------|----------|--------|
| London dispersion | Weak | Cl2, CH4 |
| Dipole-dipole | Medium | HCl, acetone |
| Hydrogen bonding | Strong | H2O, NH3 |

## Effect on Properties:

| Property | Stronger Forces = |
|----------|------------------|
| Boiling point | Higher |
| Melting point | Higher |
| Viscosity | Higher |
| Surface tension | Higher |
| Vapor pressure | Lower |

## Water's Special Properties:

Due to hydrogen bonding:
- High boiling/melting points
- Ice floats (less dense as solid)
- High heat capacity
- High surface tension
- Universal solvent

## Comparing Boiling Points:

| Compound | MW | BP (C) | Forces |
|----------|-----|--------|--------|
| CH4 | 16 | -161 | London |
| HCl | 36 | -85 | Dipole-dipole |
| H2O | 18 | 100 | H-bonding |

> **Why water is liquid at room temperature:** Despite small size, strong hydrogen bonds keep water molecules together!

slides.title: Solutions and Solubility
slides.content:
# Solutions and Solubility

**Solutions** are homogeneous mixtures of solute dissolved in solvent.

## Key Terms:

- **Solute:** Substance being dissolved (smaller amount)
- **Solvent:** Substance doing the dissolving (larger amount)
- **Solubility:** Maximum amount of solute that dissolves

## Types of Solutions:

| Solute | Solvent | Example |
|--------|---------|--------|
| Gas | Liquid | CO2 in water (soda) |
| Liquid | Liquid | Alcohol in water |
| Solid | Liquid | Salt in water |
| Gas | Gas | Air |
| Solid | Solid | Alloys |

## Like Dissolves Like:

- Polar solutes dissolve in polar solvents
- Nonpolar solutes dissolve in nonpolar solvents

| Solute Type | Best Solvent | Example |
|-------------|--------------|--------|
| Polar/ionic | Water | NaCl, sugar |
| Nonpolar | Organic (hexane) | Oils, fats |

## Factors Affecting Solubility:

### Solids in Liquids:
- Temperature up = Solubility up (usually)
- Pressure: minimal effect

### Gases in Liquids:
- Temperature up = Solubility DOWN
- Pressure up = Solubility up (Henry's Law)

## Concentration Units:

| Unit | Formula |
|------|--------|
| Molarity (M) | moles solute / L solution |
| Molality (m) | moles solute / kg solvent |
| Mass percent | (mass solute / mass solution) x 100 |
| ppm | (mass solute / mass solution) x 10^6 |

## Example:
30 g NaCl in 250 mL solution. Find molarity.
```
Moles NaCl = 30 / 58.5 = 0.513 mol
M = 0.513 / 0.250 = 2.05 M
```

> **Why warm soda goes flat:** Gases are less soluble at higher temperatures, so CO2 escapes.

slides.title: Colligative Properties
slides.content:
# Colligative Properties

**Colligative properties** depend only on the NUMBER of solute particles, not their identity.

## Four Colligative Properties:

### 1. Vapor Pressure Lowering:

- Solute particles reduce solvent at surface
- Fewer solvent molecules can escape
- Vapor pressure decreases

**Raoult's Law:**
```
P_solution = X_solvent x P_pure
```

### 2. Boiling Point Elevation:

- Solution boils at higher temperature
- Must overcome lower vapor pressure

```
Delta T_b = K_b x m x i
```

Where:
- K_b = boiling point constant
- m = molality
- i = van't Hoff factor (particles per formula unit)

### 3. Freezing Point Depression:

- Solution freezes at lower temperature
- Solute disrupts crystal formation

```
Delta T_f = K_f x m x i
```

### 4. Osmotic Pressure:

- Pressure to stop osmosis
- Solvent moves toward higher solute concentration

```
Pi = MRTi
```

## Van't Hoff Factor (i):

| Solute Type | i | Example |
|-------------|---|--------|
| Non-electrolyte | 1 | Sugar |
| NaCl | 2 | Na+ + Cl- |
| CaCl2 | 3 | Ca2+ + 2Cl- |

## Applications:

| Application | Property Used |
|-------------|---------------|
| Antifreeze | Freezing point depression |
| Road salt | Freezing point depression |
| IV fluids | Osmotic pressure |
| Cooking food | Boiling point elevation |

> **Why salt melts ice:** Salt lowers freezing point, so ice melts even below 0 C.

slides.title: Quantum Numbers and Orbitals
slides.content:
# Quantum Numbers and Orbitals

Electrons are described by four **quantum numbers**.

## The Four Quantum Numbers:

### 1. Principal Quantum Number (n):
- Values: 1, 2, 3, 4...
- Determines energy level and size
- Higher n = higher energy, larger orbital

### 2. Angular Momentum Number (l):
- Values: 0 to (n-1)
- Determines orbital shape

| l | Orbital | Shape |
|---|---------|-------|
| 0 | s | Sphere |
| 1 | p | Dumbbell |
| 2 | d | Cloverleaf |
| 3 | f | Complex |

### 3. Magnetic Quantum Number (ml):
- Values: -l to +l
- Determines orientation in space
- For p orbitals: -1, 0, +1 (three orientations)

### 4. Spin Quantum Number (ms):
- Values: +1/2 or -1/2
- Represents electron spin direction
- Two electrons per orbital must have opposite spins

## Example: 3p Orbital

- n = 3 (third shell)
- l = 1 (p orbital)
- ml = -1, 0, or +1 (three orientations)
- ms = +1/2 or -1/2 (for each electron)

## Orbital Shapes:

### s Orbital:
- Spherical
- One orientation
- Maximum 2 electrons

### p Orbital:
- Dumbbell-shaped
- Three orientations (px, py, pz)
- Maximum 6 electrons

### d Orbital:
- Cloverleaf (mostly)
- Five orientations
- Maximum 10 electrons

> **Probability clouds:** Orbitals represent regions where electrons are most likely to be found, not definite paths!

slides.title: Physical Chemistry Quiz
slides.content: Test your overall understanding!
slides.quizQuestion: Adding salt to water causes the boiling point to:

slides.title: Summary and Key Concepts
slides.content:
# Physical Chemistry Summary

## Atomic Structure:
- Atoms contain protons, neutrons, electrons
- Electrons fill orbitals following Aufbau, Pauli, Hund's rules
- Quantum numbers describe electron state

## Chemical Bonding:

| Bond Type | Formation | Example |
|-----------|-----------|--------|
| Ionic | Electron transfer | NaCl |
| Covalent | Electron sharing | H2O |
| Metallic | Electron sea | Fe |

## Intermolecular Forces:
- London dispersion (all molecules)
- Dipole-dipole (polar molecules)
- Hydrogen bonding (H with F, O, N)

## States of Matter:
- Solid: Fixed shape and volume
- Liquid: Fixed volume, variable shape
- Gas: Variable shape and volume (PV = nRT)

## Reaction Kinetics:
- Rate depends on concentration, temperature, surface area, catalyst
- Activation energy is minimum energy for reaction
- Catalysts lower activation energy

## Equilibrium:
- Forward and reverse rates equal
- K = [Products]/[Reactants]
- Le Chatelier: System counteracts stress

## Key Equations:

| Concept | Equation |
|---------|----------|
| Ideal Gas Law | PV = nRT |
| Rate Law | Rate = k[A]^m[B]^n |
| Equilibrium | K = [C]^c[D]^d / [A]^a[B]^b |
| Heat | q = mc Delta T |
| Boiling elevation | Delta T = K_b m i |

> **Congratulations!** You've completed Physical Chemistry. These principles explain the energy, structure, and behavior of all chemical systems!
